Although the paper does not provide further derivation details within the context chunks, this equation establishes how changes in membrane potential modulate the current carried by Ca²⁺ <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr> <p><strong>3. Dynamics of Intracellular Ca²⁺ Concentration</strong><br> Once inside the cell, the concentration of Ca²⁺ is dynamically regulated. This time-dependent change can be captured using a differential equation of the form</p> <p><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex- mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</ mi><mo>[</mo><mi>C</ mi><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</ mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</ mo></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</ mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</ mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>o</ mi><mi>u</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></ msub><mo>[</mo><mi>C</ mi><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</ mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</ mo><mo>+</mo><mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">(</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mtext> </ mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">)</mi></mtext><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{d[Ca^{2+}]}{dt} = -k_{out}[Ca^{2+}] + \text{(influx term)}, </annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:1.491108em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:2.177108em;vertical-align:-0.686em;"></ span><span class="base displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord reset-textstyle displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="sizing reset-size5 size5 reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.686em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle textstyle cramped"><span class="mord textstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">d</span><span class="mord mathit">t</span></span></span></span><span style="top:-0.22999999999999998em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped frac-line"></span></span><span style="top:-0.677em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathit">d</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit">a</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:-0.363em;margin-right:0.05em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathrm">2</span><span class="mbin">+</span></span></span></ span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></ span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="sizing reset-size5 size5 reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03148em;">k</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03148em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">o</span><span class="mord mathit">u</span><span class="mord mathit">t</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit">a</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:-0.41300000000000003em;margin-right:0.05em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathrm">2</span><span class="mbin">+</span></span></span></ span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="text mord displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathrm">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">i</span><span class="mord mathrm">n</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right:0.07778em;">f</span><span class="mord mathrm">l</span><span class="mord mathrm">u</span><span class="mord mathrm">x</span><span class="mord mspace"> </span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mord mathrm">e</span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="mord mathrm">)</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></ span></span></p> <p>where <span class="katex"><span class="katex- mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>k</ mi><mrow><mi>o</mi><mi>u</ mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub></ mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k_{out}</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.69444em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.84444em;vertical-align:-0.15em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03148em;">k</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03148em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">o</span><span class="mord mathit">u</span><span class="mord mathit">t</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span></span></span></span> represents the rate at which Ca²⁺ is extruded from the cytoplasm and the influx term corresponds to the Ca²⁺ entering during synaptic activity []. This formulation emphasizes the balance between Ca²⁺ entry during action potentials and its subsequent removal, a process that is fundamental for maintaining proper Ca²⁺ signaling <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr> <p><strong>4. Link Between Ca²⁺ Influx and Intracellular Signaling</strong><br> An increase in intracellular Ca²⁺—for instance, through action potential broadening which prolongs the open time of Ca²⁺ channels—leads to elevated Ca²⁺ entry. This enhanced Ca²⁺ influx is crucial because it activates Ca²⁺-dependent signaling cascades such as the ERK/MAPK pathway, which in turn promotes gene transcription (including that of GluR2) and contributes to a switch in receptor phenotype at synapses <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="1" data-page="6">[1]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="7" data-page="7">[7]</span>. Notably, pharmacological interventions that block L-type Ca²⁺ channels (e.g., using nifedipine) are shown to prevent these downstream effects, reinforcing the causal link between Ca²⁺ entry and signaling activation <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr> <p><strong>5. Summary Table of Key Properties and Functions of Ca²⁺</strong></p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th><strong>Property/Function</strong></th> <th><strong>Details</strong></th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td><strong>Charge</strong></td> <td>+2</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Typical Intracellular Concentration</strong></td> <td>Approximately 100 nM to 1 µM</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Role in Synaptic Plasticity</strong></td> <td>Modulates neurotransmitter release and synaptic strength</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Channels Involved</strong></td> <td>L-type and N-type voltage-gated calcium channels</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Downstream Effects</strong></td> <td>Activation of kinases (e.g., via the ERK/MAPK cascade) and gene transcription (e.g., GluR2)</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>This table, as provided in Section 4 of the paper, concisely summarizes how Ca²⁺ is not only an important ion for rapid electrical signaling but also a key trigger for long-term synaptic modifications [].</p> <hr> <p><strong>6. Conclusion</strong><br> In summary, the paper details a quantitative framework for understanding Ca²⁺ dynamics: the Ca²⁺ current during an action potential is governed by membrane potential and channel properties, the intracellular concentration is regulated by a balance of influx and clearance, and the resulting Ca²⁺ signal activates downstream pathways such as ERK/MAPK that lead to genetic changes and synaptic plasticity. This detailed mechanistic view underlines the precision with which neuronal activity is translated into lasting changes in synaptic strength <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="1" data-page="6">[1]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="2" data-page="5">[2]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="7" data-page="7">[7]</span>.</p> <hr> <p>Each step of the explanation is supported by data and discussions provided in the relevant sections of the paper.</p>

(3)(+0000000): 1234567890 DeepTutorChatBox: DOM-converted XML (19435 chars): <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><head></ head><body><root><p>Below is a detailed explanation of Ca²⁺ dynamics and its role in synaptic signaling in cerebellar stellate cells, using the information provided by the paper.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>1. Importance of Ca²⁺ in Synaptic Signaling</strong><br /> Calcium ions (Ca²⁺) serve as critical messengers that regulate neurotransmitter release, modulate synaptic strength, and trigger intracellular signaling cascades important for synaptic plasticity in cerebellar stellate cells <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="7" data-page="7">[7]</span>.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>2. Mathematical Description of Ca²⁺ Influx</strong><br /> During an action potential, Ca²⁺ enters the cell through voltage‐gated calcium channels, and this influx is quantitatively described by the equation</p> <p><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>I</ mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></ mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>g</ mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></ mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>V</ mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>−</ mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>C</ mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>)</ mo><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I_{Ca} = g_{Ca}(V_m - E_{Ca}), </annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.75em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:1em;vertical-align:-0.25em;"></span><span class="base displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07847em;">I</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.07847em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathit">a</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03588em;">g</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03588em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathit">a</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.22222em;">V</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.22222em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">m</span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.05764em;">E</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>I</ mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></ mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I_{Ca}</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.68333em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.83333em;vertical-align:-0.15em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07847em;">I</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.07847em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></ mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">g_{Ca}</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.43056em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.625em;vertical-align:-0.19444em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03588em;">g</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03588em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathit">a</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span></span></span></span> is the conductance of the calcium channels, <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>V</ mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V_m</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.68333em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.83333em;vertical-align:-0.15em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.22222em;">V</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.22222em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">m</span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span></span></span></span> is the membrane potential, and <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</ mi><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></ mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{Ca}</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.68333em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.83333em;vertical-align:-0.15em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.05764em;">E</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.05764em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathit">a</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span></span></span></span> is the reversal potential for Ca²⁺ []. Although the paper does not provide further derivation details within the context chunks, this equation establishes how changes in membrane potential modulate the current carried by Ca²⁺ <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>3. Dynamics of Intracellular Ca²⁺ Concentration</strong><br /> Once inside the cell, the concentration of Ca²⁺ is dynamically regulated. This time-dependent change can be captured using a differential equation of the form</p> <p><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</ mi><mo>[</mo><mi>C</ mi><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</ mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</ mo></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</ mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>−</ mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>o</ mi><mi>u</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></ msub><mo>[</mo><mi>C</ mi><msup><mi>a</mi><mrow><mn>2</ mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</ mo><mo>+</mo><mtext><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">(</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">u</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mtext xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> </mtext><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" mathvariant="normal">)</mi></mtext><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{d[Ca^{2+}]}{dt} = -k_{out}[Ca^{2+}] + \text{(influx term)}, </annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:1.491108em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:2.177108em;vertical-align:-0.686em;"></ span><span class="base displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord reset-textstyle displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="sizing reset-size5 size5 reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.686em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></ span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="sizing reset-size5 size5 reset-textstyle textstyle uncramped nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03148em;">k</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03148em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">o</span><span class="mord mathit">u</span><span class="mord mathit">t</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit">a</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:-0.41300000000000003em;margin-right:0.05em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathrm">2</span><span class="mbin">+</span></span></span></ span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="text mord displaystyle textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord mathrm">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">i</span><span class="mord mathrm">n</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right:0.07778em;">f</span><span class="mord mathrm">l</span><span class="mord mathrm">u</span><span class="mord mathrm">x</span><span class="mord mspace"> </span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mord mathrm">e</span><span class="mord mathrm">r</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="mord mathrm">)</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></ span></span></p> <p>where <span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/ MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>k</ mi><mrow><mi>o</mi><mi>u</ mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub></ mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k_{out}</annotation></ semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="strut" style="height:0.69444em;"></span><span class="strut bottom" style="height:0.84444em;vertical-align:-0.15em;"></ span><span class="base textstyle uncramped"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathit" style="margin-right:0.03148em;">k</span><span class="vlist"><span style="top:0.15em;margin-right:0.05em;margin- left:-0.03148em;"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span><span class="reset-textstyle scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord scriptstyle cramped"><span class="mord mathit">o</span><span class="mord mathit">u</span><span class="mord mathit">t</span></span></span></span><span class="baseline-fix"><span class="fontsize-ensurer reset-size5 size5"><span style="font-size:0em;">​</span></span>​</span></ span></span></span></span></span> represents the rate at which Ca²⁺ is extruded from the cytoplasm and the influx term corresponds to the Ca²⁺ entering during synaptic activity []. This formulation emphasizes the balance between Ca²⁺ entry during action potentials and its subsequent removal, a process that is fundamental for maintaining proper Ca²⁺ signaling <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>4. Link Between Ca²⁺ Influx and Intracellular Signaling</strong><br /> An increase in intracellular Ca²⁺—for instance, through action potential broadening which prolongs the open time of Ca²⁺ channels—leads to elevated Ca²⁺ entry. This enhanced Ca²⁺ influx is crucial because it activates Ca²⁺-dependent signaling cascades such as the ERK/MAPK pathway, which in turn promotes gene transcription (including that of GluR2) and contributes to a switch in receptor phenotype at synapses <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="1" data-page="6">[1]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="7" data-page="7">[7]</span>. Notably, pharmacological interventions that block L-type Ca²⁺ channels (e.g., using nifedipine) are shown to prevent these downstream effects, reinforcing the causal link between Ca²⁺ entry and signaling activation <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span>.</p> <hr /> <p><strong>5. Summary Table of Key Properties and Functions of Ca²⁺</strong></p> <table> <thead> <tr> <th><strong>Property/Function</strong></th> <th><strong>Details</strong></th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <td><strong>Charge</strong></td> <td>+2</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Typical Intracellular Concentration</strong></td> <td>Approximately 100 nM to 1 µM</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Role in Synaptic Plasticity</strong></td> <td>Modulates neurotransmitter release and synaptic strength</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Channels Involved</strong></td> <td>L-type and N-type voltage-gated calcium channels</td> </tr> <tr> <td><strong>Downstream Effects</strong></td> <td>Activation of kinases (e.g., via the ERK/MAPK cascade) and gene transcription (e.g., GluR2)</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>This table, as provided in Section 4 of the paper, concisely summarizes how Ca²⁺ is not only an important ion for rapid electrical signaling but also a key trigger for long-term synaptic modifications [].</p> <hr /> <p><strong>6. Conclusion</strong><br /> In summary, the paper details a quantitative framework for understanding Ca²⁺ dynamics: the Ca²⁺ current during an action potential is governed by membrane potential and channel properties, the intracellular concentration is regulated by a balance of influx and clearance, and the resulting Ca²⁺ signal activates downstream pathways such as ERK/MAPK that lead to genetic changes and synaptic plasticity. This detailed mechanistic view underlines the precision with which neuronal activity is translated into lasting changes in synaptic strength <span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="1" data-page="6">[1]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="2" data-page="5">[2]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="5" data-page="5">[5]</span><span class="deeptutor-source-placeholder" data-source-id="7" data-page="7">[7]</span>.</p> <hr /> <p>Each step of the explanation is supported by data and discussions provided in the relevant sections of the paper.</p> </root></body></html>

(3) (+0000000): DeepTutorChatBox: Setting find query to "Figure 4 Increasing the action potential duration in stellate cells induces a change in rectification of the I-V relationship. (a) The duration of spontaneous action potentials in cerebellar stellate cells increased during bath application of TEA at 22–25 °C. (b) sEPSCs had a nearly linear I-V relationship following TEA treatment (control, n = 5; TEA treatment, n = 6). Cerebellar slices were incubated with kynurenic acid (1 mM) and picrotoxin (100 µM) in the absence (control) or presence of TEA (1 mM, 3 h). (c) Summary of rectification index (RI) of EPSCs. Cerebellar slices were incubated with 100 µM picrotoxin (n = 5; control, n = 4) or with 1 mM TEA for 3 h (at 37 °C, n = 3; at 22–25 °C, n = 6). (d) The decay time of sEPSCs increased following TEA treatment (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, P < 0.0001). *P < 0.05, **P < 0.005 and ***P < 0.0005. Error bars represent ± s.e.m."
